author: timbeiko
content:
Hi all, 

Here are a few important portal updates following the Ethereum Foundation’s recent reorg:

1. The EF will no longer be maintaining its portal implementations (Trin & Ultralight). All code will remain available and open source, but we do not expect active development to continue.
2. We have begun reaching out to external portal implementers about grants and will continue to do so over the coming weeks. If this concerns you and you have not yet heard from the EF, please ping <@543900561460822016> 
3. For pre-merge expiry, we will update https://eth-clients.github.io/history-endpoints and include instructions for all clients on both mainnet and Sepolia. Expect an announcement soon! 

Some teams may choose to use Portal’s history network, but going forward we expect this to be decoupled from history expiry work.

author: .fjl
content:
The key change, on the EF side, is that Portal as a standalone client is not being considered a goal anymore. The history network is a useful idea and we will pursue integration in Geth still.

This has implications. If you wanted to connect to Portal with a standalone client, you'd need to get light client proofs of headers to verify the canon chain. But if we just see it as a store of history, we don't need the proofs anymore since the EL nodes have the header chain available and can always cross check against it.

author: .fjl
content: We will likely still serve the headers in Portal, and you could build a standalone client if you have a source of beacon chain proofs, but the EL nodes won't use the beacon network, at least not in the foreseeable future. It's a scope change. Notably, with this change, there is also no need to run dedicated bridges since all EL nodes generate the history by themselves.

author: .fjl
content: We are still discussing here how to best fit this in with the new structure at EF, and who will be able to do the work. Let's aim for a group call some time end of next week to discuss together.
